Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: MRI Consortium: Development of a Novel Telescope for Very High-Energy Gamma-Ray Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Very high-energy (VHE) gamma-ray astrophysics has been transformed by a number of stunning discoveries made by the current-generation, ground-based gamma-ray observatories operating in the 100 GeV - 10 TeV energy range. These observatories are arrays of 2-4 imaging atmospheric Cherenkov telescopes (IACTs) that detect VHE gamma-rays via Cherenkov light from secondary electrons in electromagnetic cascades initiated by gamma-rays in the atmosphere. Developing new instruments with significantly better sensitivity is not possible by a simple replication or upgrade of existing devices.

With this award, the proponents will build a novel gamma-ray telescope that has the potential to transform the field, based on work by Schwarzschild and Couder. It incorporates original ideas for the optics, mechanics, and electronics to achieve substantial gains in angular resolution and field of view at costs comparable to existing instruments. The international Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA) Consortium is preparing for a future IACT array with ten times better sensitivity and broader energy coverage to exploit the evident scientific potential of VHE gamma-ray observations. Some examples of new types of gamma-ray discoveries are searching extremely deeply for dark matter in the Galactic center and halo, testing cosmology with extragalactic background light measurements, resolving the details of shock acceleration in supernova remnants and pulsar winds, and advancing the physics of extragalactic jets by population studies and observations of short-term variability.

This new telescope overcomes the fundamental limitations in angular resolution and field of view of current prime-focus IACTs. At the same time, it allows the application of new, lower-cost technologies for the camera focal plane sensors. This work will demonstrate the enhanced performance and improved reliability of the SCT design, and the location adjacent to VERITAS will allow the performance to be evaluated against an instrument of known sensitivity. The results from this effort will enable informed choices to be made for the construction of CTA or other future instruments. It will also enhance the capabilities of the VERITAS Observatory.

Broader Impact: Working with industry, this work will foster emerging technologies for the mass production of relatively inexpensive, light, aspheric mirror segments that will both enable future instruments to deliver unique science capabilities and encourage use of the design in the other fields of astronomy. This project will provide a unique opportunity for integrated research and education for a substantial number of young scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Very high-energy (VHE) gamma-ray astrophysics has grown to maturity during the last fifty years utilizing small arrays of large aperture imaging atmospheric Cherenkov telescopes (IACTs), with optical systems that are based on a single mirror, prime-focus Davies-Cotton or parabolic design. These conventional IACTs, although adequate for all present-day ground-based observatories -- VERITAS, H.E.S.S. and MAGIC -- have become a limiting factor of the performance of the Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA), the next generation world-wide observatory currently under design and construction. This project built and demonstrated the innovative 9.7-m dual-mirror prototype Schwarzschild-Couder Telescope (pSCT) for CTA, which has the potential to transform the field by offering major improvements of angular resolution and off-axis sensitivity in the wide 8-degree field-of-view. The pSCT, which incorporates original ideas for the optics, mechanics, and electronics, is delivered at a cost comparable to the existing IACTs of similar aperture. It has been built at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory (Figures 1 and 2) and operated as a stand-alone instrument as well as in conjunction with the co-located VERITAS observatory.  The pSCT was inaugurated (Figure 3) and achieved first light in January 2019, at the completion of construction.

The breakthrough of the pSCT in IACT technology is realized by utilizing the Schwarzschild-Couder optical system (OS), which consists of a 9.7-m segmented primary mirror and a 5.4-m segmented secondary mirror, together configured to correct comatic aberrations and simultaneously reduce the focal plane plate scale by a factor of three compared to conventional IACT designs. The 72 aspheric light-weight hybrid mirror panels have been produced in collaboration with industry by employing cost-effective hot and cold glass slumping replication technologies.  A total of 432 actuators, 306 edge sensors and 72 microcomputers are used to align the OS and deliver an optical point-spread function of 3.3 arcmin (twice the Gaussian sigma along the major axis), as shown in Figure 4. Although this value already reaches the design specification, further alignment improvement is feasible.

The unique combination of high-resolution imaging in the 8-degree field-of-view with the small plate scale of the pSCT enables the construction of a compact camera, less than 1 meter in diameter, in which all the front-end and back-end high density electronics (with 1 ns digitization speed) are located behind the photosensors.  The photosensors are novel semiconductor photon sensitive devices, silicon photomultipliers, which have higher photon detection efficiency and are less expensive than the traditional photomultipliers used in present-day gamma-ray observatories. The demonstration prototype pSCT camera consisting of 1,600 pixels in the 2.7o x 2.7o field exceeds the pixel count of three VERITAS telescopes and represents another technology development achievement of the project. The fully populated 8 degree pSCT camera under construction (funded by a separate, on-going NSF award) will have 11,328 pixels, which is 6.3 times larger than the conventional IACT design for CTA.  An image of a TeV gamma-ray-initiated atmospheric cascade recorded by the prototype pSCT camera is shown in Figure 5, demonstrating the capability of this innovative instrumentation.

The pSCT technology was validated by the detection of the Crab Nebula, an established gamma-ray source. A few hours of pSCT data were taken while VERITAS was also observing the Crab Nebula, allowing the cross-calibration of gamma-ray events observed with both instruments and the optimization of background rejection for stand-alone pSCT data.  The analysis methods refined on the pSCT-VERITAS combined data set were applied to an independent sample of about 20 hours of pSCT-only data, yielding a more than 8 standard deviation (sigma) detection of the gamma-ray signal from the Crab Nebula, shown in Figure 6.  This initial detection of a gamma-ray source verifies the end-to-end performance of the pSCT as a new design of IACT for CTA capable of recording images of gamma-ray showers with unsurpassed resolution.

Further validation of the pSCT technology and its advantages for CTA is being planned with the continued operation of the telescope and refinement of the analysis methods, in conjunction with an upgrade of the camera to instrument the full 8-degree field of view with significantly improved photosensors and advanced electronics. The assessment of the pSCT performance notably benefits from the co-location with the VERITAS observatory, and the existing VERITAS science capabilities are expected to be augmented with the wide field-of-view, high angular resolution and off-axis sensitivity of the pSCT.
